stream_context.summary: Kaze programmed the AI and physics for two new enemies in a craft-themed level: the 'Thimble Guy' and 'Bert the Bashful'. This involved significant technical debugging of a graphical effect. He also conducted a detailed review and hardware test of a major visual overhaul for Course 1, submitted by artist Biobak, and provided critical feedback on a new music track from composer Badub.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging a graphical effect, ultimately discovering the issue was a shadowed variable that the compiler didn't warn him about. He had to inspect the generated assembly code to find the bug.
development_findings.quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC.

development_findings.summary: The 'Thimble Guy' enemies are designed to be defeated not by a standard stomp, but by knocking them off ledges, similar to the Bullies in Super Mario 64. This interaction required custom physics programming.
development_findings.quote: I was thinking they should work more like bully fights where you kick them off the thing.

development_findings.summary: The project is planned to have approximately 30 levels in total, comprising 15 main courses. The stream focused on work for the 14th main course.
The game will feature a large number of collectibles, including main stars and special 'Yoshi stars' which impose unique challenges on the player, such as A-press limits.
development_findings.quote: We're gonna have, I think, around 135 main stars. And then we're gonna have 45 Yoshi stars. These Yoshi stars are missions that Yoshi's give you that have like special restrictions... there's 11 types in total.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is considering releasing the game's original soundtrack on a physical N64 cartridge as a piece of merchandise.
development_findings.quote: I think it would just be really cool to release a separate cartridge that isn't just the OST. Because then we could sell it too as merch.

development_findings.summary: A new enemy, based on Bert the Bashful, is being designed. The creative goal is to make it look like a 'handcrafted' painted egg with a pom-pom nose, but the initial model looks too 'cheap'.
development_findings.quote: He's supposed to be a painted egg... I like him, but he doesn't look very handcrafted.

development_findings.summary: Kaze confirmed that the performance of Biobak's visually upgraded Course 1 was roughly the same as the old version on N64 hardware, which he considered a success with room for more optimization.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is aware of potential legal issues with Nintendo, especially after they took down a video for his previous project, and plans to seek legal advice before the game's release.
context_findings.quote: I will probably talk to a lawyer Before I release R.T.Y.I.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a fringe, ironic-sounding view on software development, linking the use of premade game engines to being 'woke' and associating custom engine development with being 'not woke'.
context_findings.quote: The thing about woke people is they can't program, which is why they have to use premade engines like Unreal Engine or Unity or Godot, right? So if you use your own engine, it's not woke anymore. I learned this yesterday on Twitter.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has a grand vision for the game's overworld to be a complete, explorable representation of Yoshi's Island, where progression unlocks deeper areas of the island.
context_findings.quote: I was thinking for the overworld. It is super important that the overworld is the entirety of Yoshi's Island. It is important that you get like a 360Â° round view... so it feels like you can actually explore the entire island.

context_findings.summary: After being approached for a job by an AI data company, Kaze formed a strong negative opinion on the utility and future of Large Language Models (LLMs).
context_findings.quote: I have just gotten 100% sure that all large language models are just garbage. Just paddling. It's not going anywhere. It's not gonna be ever useful. Other than a better Google.

context_findings.summary: Kaze distinguishes between being a musician (composer) and simply playing an instrument, which he dismissively refers to as a 'party trick'.
context_findings.quote: I keep saying, learning to play an instrument is just a party trick. And this is just another proof of that. People are saying it's a bad take. I think it's a great take.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has moved from Germany to Canada and expresses strong negative feelings about German bureaucracy, stating it ruined his quality of life even after leaving.

biobak.summary: Biobak completed a major visual and performance rework of Course 1, significantly reducing the polygon and material count while overhauling the aesthetics with new models, textures, and background elements.
biobak.quote: Quick facts, 220 fewer tries, 7 fewer materials, that is insane.

biobak.summary: There is a technical dependency where Kaze needs to fix texture formats in Biobak's work because Biobak lacks the setup to test his assets directly on N64 hardware.
biobak.quote: I have to fix formats from Biobak's file. Because he doesn't always know what the correct formats are... he can't export this thing. So he can't check it.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided a detailed changelog for his level rework, explaining the rationale behind changes like removing trees to reduce overdraw and altering the map's shape to look 'less like a penis'.

badub.summary: Badub composed a track for the craft-themed level. While Kaze's audience liked it, Kaze provided critical feedback that it didn't fit the level's adventurous tone and lacked a hummable melody.
badub.quote: It doesn't fit the vibe. Feels more like a beach at sunset. Not like a complete adventure, you know. And I'm also kinda missing the melody that you can hum along to.

zeina.summary: Zeina was mentioned in a personal context; Kaze has recently started playing Minecraft with her for the first time.

key_stories.title: The Shadowed Variable Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to implement a moving shine effect on an enemy. After extensive debugging across different platforms, he traced the problem to a subtle compiler bug caused by a shadowed variable, which he could only find by reading the generated assembly code. The incident highlights the deep technical challenges of N64 development and the limitations of tooling.
key_stories.challenge: A graphical effect for a dynamic shine on an enemy's head was not working, with the texture refusing to move despite the code seeming correct.
key_stories.process: Kaze attempted to implement the shine using a standard technique. When it failed, he tested it on multiple emulators (Project64, Nemu) and real hardware, each yielding different broken results. Suspecting a compiler issue, he examined the raw assembly code and discovered the compiler had misinterpreted his C code due to a variable name being reused in a nested scope. He later confirmed that ChatGPT could have identified the error instantly.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze found the bug was a shadowed variable. He fixed it and added a compiler flag (-Wshadow) to prevent similar issues. He also discovered the effect was incompatible with 'clamped' textures, requiring a design workaround.
key_stories.key_quote: And this is why you don't trust your fucking compiler. You look at the assembly and then you find it out. Fuck you, GCC. Why didn't you warn me?

key_stories.title: Critiquing the Level's Music
key_stories.summary: Kaze reviewed a new music track from composer Badub for a level. Despite the audience's positive reaction, Kaze determined the song's vibe was a mismatch for the level's adventurous theme, providing specific creative feedback. This story illustrates Kaze's role in maintaining the project's creative direction and the dynamic of giving critical feedback to a teammate.
key_stories.challenge: The team's composer, Badub, created a song for the new craft-themed level, but Kaze needed to evaluate if it fit the game's creative vision.
key_stories.process: Kaze first played the song for his audience to gather their unbiased opinions. After they responded positively, he shared his own critique, explaining that while he found it beautiful, it felt more melancholic and relaxing than adventurous and lacked a strong, hummable melody suitable for a Mario game.
key_stories.outcome: While the chat praised the music, Kaze concluded it was not a good fit for the level's intended feel. The music is creatively misaligned, leaving an open question of how the team will proceed with the level's soundtrack.
key_stories.key_quote: It doesn't fit the vibe. Feels more like a beach at sunset. Not like a complete adventure, you know.

key_stories.title: The Course 1 Rework
key_stories.summary: Graphics artist Biobak delivered a massive rework of Course 1. Kaze reviewed the extensive changes on stream, which included significant model and texture optimizations, and then tested it on hardware. The result was a huge visual improvement with no performance loss, demonstrating a successful collaboration and a major milestone for the project.
key_stories.challenge: Course 1, an early level, needed a significant visual and performance overhaul.
key_stories.process: Biobak, the graphics artist, independently reworked the entire level. Kaze received the files and a detailed changelog during the stream. He went through the changes one by one, providing commentary, before exporting the level and testing its appearance and performance in-game on an emulator and on original N64 hardware.
key_stories.outcome: The reworked level was a major success. It looked significantly better, ran at the same frame rate despite the visual upgrade, and had potential for even more optimization. Kaze was extremely pleased and planned to integrate it into the game.
key_stories.key_quote: 220 fewer tries, 7 fewer materials, that is insane.
